facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 998 of 1965 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 998 of 1965.

facts.text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated February 24, 25, 1964 of the Bombay High Court, Nagpur Bench in Special Civil Application 459 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated February 24, 25, 1964 of the Bombay High Court, Nagpur Bench in Special Civil Application 459 of 1963.

facts.text: The appellant is a mining proprietor and holds several manganese mines in different States.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is a mining proprietor and holds several manganese mines in different States.

facts.text: The appellant has been doing business in many articles apart from being an exporter of manganese ore.

anchor.surface_text: He has also been doing business in many articles apart from being an exporter of manganese ore.

facts.text: Assistant Collector of Customs and Central Excise Raipur issued an authorization for searching the premises of the appellant based on information that the appellant was in possession of a large quantity of undeclared gold.

anchor.surface_text: On information alleged to have been received to the effect of that the appellant was in possession of a large quantity of undeclared gold the Assistant Collector of Customs and Central Exercise Raipur issued an authorization under r. 126  L 4 2  of the Defence of India  Amendment  Rules, 1963  Gold Control Rules  hereinafter called the Rules, for searching the premises of the appellant.

facts.text: The authorization was issued under r. 126 L 4 2 of the Defence of India Amendment Rules, 1963 Gold Control Rules.

anchor.surface_text: ...under r. 126  L 4 2  of the Defence of India  Amendment  Rules, 1963  Gold Control Rules  hereinafter called the Rules, for searching the premises of the appellant.

facts.text: The appellant's premises were searched pursuant to the authorization.

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to that authorization, the appellants premises were searched...

facts.text: As a result of the search, gold and other articles, foreign currency and other documents were seized.

anchor.surface_text: ...and as a result of the search gold and other articles, foreign currency and other documents. were seized.

facts.text: The appellant filed a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution in the High Court of Bombay Nagpur Bench challenging the validity of the search and seizure.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant filed a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution in the High Court of Bombay  Nagpur Bench  challenging the validity of the said search and the seizure of the articles and documents belonging to him.

facts.text: The petition was Special Civil Application 459 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: ...in Special Civil Application 459 of 1963.

facts.text: The High Court heard the petition along with similar petitions filed by other persons whose premises were searched and goods seized.

anchor.surface_text: The petition was heard along with similar petitions filed by other persons whose premises were likewise searched and goods and documents seized therefrom.

facts.text: The High Court dismissed all the petitions.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court dismissed all the petitions.

facts.text: Several petitioners including the appellant preferred appeals to the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The several petitioners before the High Court, along with the appellant, preferred appeals to this Court...

facts.text: Other appeals were heard by the Supreme Court in Durg Prasad v. H.R. Gomes and dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: ...and the an appeals other than that filed by the appellant were heard by this Court See Durg Prasad v. H.R. Gomes, Superintendent  Prevention , Central Exercise Nagpur 1 . Therein this Court companysidered the various companytentions raised by them and dismissed the same.

facts.text: This appeal was not heard along with the other appeals.

anchor.surface_text: For one reason or other, this appeal was number heard along with them.

facts.text: The appellant contended that the Assistant Collector and the officer acted with mala fides.

anchor.surface_text: The companytention that the Assistant Collector and the officer authorized by him to make the search acted with mala fides...

facts.text: The High Court considered the evidence and rejected the mala fides contention.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court companysidered the evidence and rejected it.

facts.text: The Supreme Court found no justification to take a different view on mala fides.

anchor.surface_text: We do number see any justification to take a different view on the material placed before us.

facts.text: The authorization stated: Whereas information has been laid before me of the suspected commission of offence under section 11 read with section 111 of the Customs Act 1962.

anchor.surface_text: The relevant part of the authorization reads thus Whereas information has been laid before me of the suspected companymission of offence under section 11 read with section 111 of the Customs Act 1962  52 of 1962  and it has been made to appear that the production of companytraband goods and documents relating thereto are essential to the enquiry about to be made in the suspected offence

facts.text: Three years have elapsed since the documents were seized and nothing further has been done.

anchor.surface_text: It is represented to us that three years have elapsed since the documents were seized and it appears that numberhing further has been done in the matter.

facts.text: The High Court held that the Assistant Collector had acted with reasonable belief.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, on the material placed before it, held that the Assistant Collector had acted with reasonable belief in the facts mentioned in that section.

facts.text: The Supreme Court appeal was dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeal fails and is dismissed with companyts.

issues.text: whether the search of the premises of the appellant and the seizure of the articles and the documents found therein were valid

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by certificate raises the quest on whether the search of the premises of the appellant and the seizure of the articles and the documents found therein were valid.

issues.text: whether the Assistant Collector and the officer authorized by him to make the search acted with mala fides

anchor.surface_text: The contention that the Assistant Collector and the officer authorized by him to make the search acted with mala fides has nosubstance.

issues.text: whether under s. 105 of the Customs Act the Assistant Collector shall have reason to believe that some goods are secreted before he can authorize any officer of Customs to search for them or the relevant documents, but the authorization given by the Assistant Collector to the Customs Officer did not say that he had reason to believe so

anchor.surface_text: The second contention is that under s. 105 of the Customs Act, hereinafter called the Act, the Assistant Collector shall have reason to believe

anchor.surface_text: The next argument is based upon the provisions of s. 110 of the Act. Under s. 110(3) of the Act only a proper officer can seize any documents

arguments.claim: On reasonable construction of s. 105, Assistant Collector must give reasons for belief and particulars of goods/documents in authorization

anchor.surface_text: The next contention is that on a reasonable construction of the said provision it should be held that the Assistant Collector of Customs should not only give reasons for his belief but also the particulars of the nature of the goods and of the documents, for, if the reasons and the particulars are not given the officer authorized may make a roving search

court_response_anchor.surface_text: hich is number in the companytemplation of the said section. This argument may be dealt with in two parts. In terms S. 105 of the Act does number say

arguments.court_reasoning: S.105 does not require stating reasons or particulars; non-mention does not vitiate; particulars not feasible before search; authorization sufficiently specified

arguments.claim: Under s.110(3), only proper officer can seize; seizing officer not proper officer per s.2(34) as only Board assigns, not Collector

anchor.surface_text: The next argument is based upon the provisions of s. 110 of the Act. Under s. 110(3) of the Act only a proper officer can seize any documents or goods which in his opinion will be useful for or relevant to any proceedings under the Act. Proper officer has been defined by s. 2(34) of the Act thus... It is contended that, on a true construction of s. 2(34) of the Act the Collector of Customs should himself seize the goods, that he has no power to authorize another

court_response_anchor.surface_text: at the Collector of Customs cannot assign but can function personally. The companytroversial expression in s. 2 34  is by the Board or the Collector o

arguments.court_reasoning: Fair reading: 'by' refers to both Board and Collector; both can assign functions

arguments.claim: Search void for non-compliance with CrPC provisions, esp. s.165(1) requiring recording grounds of belief

anchor.surface_text: It is then contended that the search made was void inasmuch as in making the search the relevant provisions of Code of Criminal Procedure had not been complied with. This argument is based upon S. 105(2) of the Act... The argument is that the expression so far as may be in s. 105(2) of the Act attracts s. 165(1) of the Code of Criminal Procedure and under that section, as the police-officer has to record in writing the grounds of his belief the Assistant Collector of Customs shall also in authorizing the search record his reasons

court_response_anchor.surface_text: belief and specifying in such writing, so far as possible, the thing for which search is to be made, search, or cause search to be made, for such thin

arguments.court_reasoning: s.105 and s.165(1) meet different situations; s.165 for urgent searches without warrant; not applicable to s.105

arguments.claim: s.105 confers unguided/arbitrary power on Assistant Collector, only subjective satisfaction, no policy/control, offends Art.14

anchor.surface_text: Then it is contended that s. 105 of the Act confers an unguided and arbitrary power on the Assistant Collector of Customs to make a search, the only condition being that he has reason to believe in the existence of the facts mentioned therein. It is said that the said belief is practically a subjective satisfaction and the section neither lays down any policy nor imposes any effective control

court_response_anchor.surface_text: him to make a search urgently in a case where search warrants in the ordinary companyrse cannot be obtained. It is, therefore, number possible to inv

arguments.court_reasoning: Policy laid down (search for confiscable goods/documents); controls via evidence requirement, s.165(5) reporting, s.136(2) criminal liability; does not offend Art.14

arguments.claim: Assistant Collector placed no material before High Court to sustain reasonable belief

anchor.surface_text: Lastly, it is contended that the Assistant Collector of Customs in fact has not placed any material before the High Court to sustain his reasonable belief.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: erence with the findings of the High Court. In the result, the appeal fails and is dismissed with co

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court held on material that acted with reasonable belief; no justification to interfere

arguments.claim: Points covered in Durg Prasad v. H.R. Gomes not to be reagitated

anchor.surface_text: the appeals other than that filed by the appellant were heard by this Court See Durg Prasad v. H.R. Gomes... Obviously the points covered by that judgment cannot be permitted to be reagitated in this appeal.

Nor can we agree... that the particulars... should be given... he cannot give the particulars of the documents, for they will be known only after the search is made.

holdings.text: The search of the premises of the appellant and the seizure of the articles and the documents found therein were valid.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by certificate raises the quest on whether the search of the premises of the appellant and the seizure of the articles and the documents found therein were valid.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court rejected all petitioner contentions on validity, affirmed High Court dismissal, dismissed appeal.

holdings.text: The Assistant Collector and the officer authorized by him to make the search did not act with mala fides.

anchor.surface_text: The contention that the Assistant Collector and the officer authorized by him to make the search acted with mala fides has nosubstance. The High Court considered the evidence and rejected it. We do number see any justification to take a different view on the material placed before us.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court considered evidence and rejected; Supreme Court found no justification to differ.

holdings.text: Though the words 'reason to believe' are not in terms embodied in the authorisation, the phraseology used in effect and substance meant the same thing.

anchor.surface_text: The relevant part of the authorization reads thus Whereas information has been laid before me of the suspected commission of offence under section 11 read with section 111 of the Customs Act 1962  52 of 1962  and it has been made to appear that the production of contraband goods and documents relating thereto are essential to the enquiry about to be made in the suspected offence Though the words reason to believe are number in terms embodied in the authorisation, the phraseology used in effect and substance meant the same thing.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Authorization language equivalent to 'reason to believe' requirement under s.105.

holdings.text: S. 105 of the Act does not say that the Assistant Collector shall give reasons or particulars of goods/documents; non-mention does not vitiate the order.

anchor.surface_text: In terms S. 105 of the Act does number say that the Assistant Collector shall give reasons. The power companyferred on him under S. 105 is number subject to any such companydition. Though he cannot make a search or authorize any officer to make a search A.I.R. 1966 S.C. 1209. unless he has reason to believe the existence of the facts mentioned in the section, the section does number compel him to give reasons. While it may be advisable, and indeed proper, for him to give reasons, the number-mention of reasons in itself does number vitiate the order. Nor can we agree...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory text lacks requirement; particulars not feasible pre-search; authorization sufficiently specified.

holdings.text: A fair reading of s.2(34) is that 'by' refers both to the Board and the Collector; both can assign functions to an officer of Customs.

anchor.surface_text: A fair reading of the provision, in our view, is that the preposition by refers both to the Board and the Collector. Both the Board and the Collector of Customs can assign functions to an officer of Customs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of definition allows Collector to assign, making seizing officer proper.

holdings.text: s.105 of the Act and s.165(1) CrPC meet different situations; recording grounds under s.165(1) not applicable to s.105.

anchor.surface_text: But, in our view, s. 105 of the Act and s. 165 1  of the Code of Criminal Procedure are intended to meet totally different situations. While under s. 105 of the Act the Assistant Collector of Customs either makes the search personally or authorizes any officer of Customs to do so, if he has reason to believe the facts mentioned therein, under s. 165 1  of the Code of Criminal Procedure the recording of the reasons for believing the facts is only to enable him to make a search urgently in a case where search warrants in the ordinary course cannot be obtained. It is, therefore, number possible to invoke that condition and apply it to a situation arising under s. 105 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Different contexts: s.105 not urgent warrantless search like s.165(1).

holdings.text: s.105 does not confer unguided/arbitrary power and does not offend Art.14; policy laid down with effective controls.

anchor.surface_text: Then it is contended that s. 105 of the Act confers an unguided  and arbitrary power on the Assistant Collector of Customs to make a search,. the only condition being that he has reason to believe in the existence of the facts mentioned therein... It is, therefore, clear that number only a policy is laid down in S. 105, but also that the acts of the Assistant Collector are effectively controlled in the manner stated above. We cannot, therefore, say that s. 105 offends Art. 14 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Policy for confiscable goods/documents; checks via evidence, reporting, criminal liability under ss.136(2),165(5).

holdings.text: The Assistant Collector acted with reasonable belief, as held by High Court on material; no interference justified.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, on the material placed before it, held that the Assistant Collector had acted with reasonable belief in the facts mentioned in that section. There is numberjustification for our interference with the findings of the High Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court finding on evidence sustained; no basis to differ.

holdings.text: Points covered by judgment in Durg Prasad v. H.R. Gomes cannot be reagitated.

anchor.surface_text: the an appeals other than that filed by the appellant were heard by this Court See Durg Prasad v. H.R. Gomes, Superintendent  Prevention , Central Exercise Nagpur 1 . Therein this Court considered the various contentions raised by them and dismissed the same. For one reason or other, this appeal was number heard along with them. Obviously the points covered by that judgment cannot be permitted to be reagitated in this appeal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prior Supreme Court decision binding; not heard together but applies.

anchor.surface_text: The relevant part of the authorization reads thus Whereas information has been laid before me of the suspected commission of offence under section 11 read with section 111 of the Customs Act 1962  52 of 1962  and it has been made to appear that the production of contraband goods and documents relating thereto are essential to the enquiry about to be made in the suspected offence Though the words reason to believe are number in terms embodied in the authorisation, the phraseology used in effect and substance meant the same thing.
In the result, the appeal fails and is dismissed with costs.

edges.explanation: h4 holds that s.105 does not require stating reasons or particulars, aligning with and supporting c15's stance that reasons need not be recorded unless specified

anchor.surface_text: In terms S. 105 of the Act does number say that the Assistant Collector shall give reasons. The power companyferred on him under S. 105 is number subject to any such companydition. Though he cannot make a search or authorize any officer to make a search A.I.R. 1966 S.C. 1209. unless he has reason to believe the existence of the facts mentioned in the section, the section does number compel him to give reasons. While it may be advisable, and indeed proper, for him to give reasons, the number-mention of reasons in itself does number vitiate the order. Nor can we agree...
In the result, the appeal fails and is dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: A fair reading of the provision, in our view, is that the preposition by refers both to the Board and the Collector. Both the Board and the Collector of Customs can assign functions to an officer of Customs.
In the result, the appeal fails and is dismissed with costs.

edges.explanation: Holding determines s.165(1) not applicable to s.105 searches, directly addressing the issue of voidness due to non-compliance with s.165(1)

anchor.surface_text: But, in our view, s. 105 of the Act and s. 165 1  of the Code of Criminal Procedure are intended to meet totally different situations. While under s. 105 of the Act the Assistant Collector of Customs either makes the search personally or authorizes any officer of Customs to do so, if he has reason to believe the facts mentioned therein, under s. 165 1  of the Code of Criminal Procedure the recording of the reasons for believing the facts is only to enable him to make a search urgently in a case where search warrants in the ordinary course cannot be obtained. It is, therefore, number possible to invoke that condition and apply it to a situation arising under s. 105 of the Act.
In the result, the appeal fails and is dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: Then it is contended that s. 105 of the Act confers an unguided  and arbitrary power on the Assistant Collector of Customs to make a search,. the only condition being that he has reason to believe in the existence of the facts mentioned therein... It is, therefore, clear that number only a policy is laid down in S. 105, but also that the acts of the Assistant Collector are effectively controlled in the manner stated above. We cannot, therefore, say that s. 105 offends Art. 14 of the Constitution.
In the result, the appeal fails and is dismissed with costs.
